text:
<@U2KJHTPQT> it seems to be 30s from our test, and it seems to be a hard coded one.
And this timeout leads to the issue here <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1163>

<@U2X9KDDL7> , at the moment, i am recording errors on the world state, then having a function to retrieve the error message. I see ERR log on the peer, but i would like too to have the error propagated
<@U0PB67X4K> It was just a thought . Some people have high frequency constraints.
Does anyone know how I would go about sending an Invoke or Query call from another Go program? (Rather than using the Node or Java SDKs)
Is it possible to connect another peer (say, vp4) to the Bluemix Blockchain Service? What would the _enrollsecret_ be?
you can use HTTP or GRPC calls

text: <@U0N4D2T61> Thanks. I was just looking into grpc. Am I right in thinking that GRPC is preferred? From a security point of view
NodeSDK is using GRPC, new JavaSDK too. HTTP will be deprecated soon

text: <@U2W7U5UA3> .proto from Fabric, js or java classes are included on SDK. Otherwise you will have to generate the output files yourself
<@U3CB63BTP|jgcarv> has joined the channel

I found why it's empty. You should just pass `attrs` argument on HFC invoke. More details in this example
<https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/car-lease-demo/blob/master/Server_Side/tools/utils/util.js#L31>
Hope it will help someone else!

text: <@U3D45J2FK|colyerfs> has joined the channel

Hi guys I'm working on a new fabric project, and I'm doing my first cloud application - I'm looking for some advice on what consensus options I have with these considerations: 1. Need one network node on an AWS server 2. Several developer machines connecting intermittently on the network
can I use noops in this case?
if you only have one node, you probably don't have much of a choice
that's what I figured, pbft can't run without other nodes - the developer machines are only going to be connected intermittently so they'd essentially be NVP's
right
<@U20M776SW|mdavid> has joined the channel

Hi, I'm now evaluating latest fabric (pre v1.0 or 0.7 ??).  I wonder if I can still use "membersrvc" which comes with 0.6 for CA or not.  Looks like COP project does not provide Docker image (I heard it's under plan, and heavy development is expected in this month).
There is no docker image for COP but it is also very easy to install as follows
go get <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-cop/cli|github.com/hyperledger/fabric-cop/cli>
For now, you'll need one other command as follows
mv $GOPATH/bin/cli $GOPATH/bin/cop
or if you have $GOROOT set ...
mv $GOROOT/bin/cli $GOROOT/bin/cop
go 1.6 is the only prereq
See <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-cop> for the readme

attachments.title: hyperledger/fabric-cop
attachments.text: This is a read-only mirror of <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/admin/projects/fabric-cop> no pull requests accepted

text: That said, you can monitor the following change sets for when docker and docker-compose are merged
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2847/>
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3161/>
<@U0S5KF44D> Thanks for the info. I'll experiment with COP on native env. for now, and watch those pull requests.

hi all, i have setup 2 peers on different machines, in hyperledger explorer's network information section it shows same IP of both peers i.e. 172.17.0.2. How can i give different IP's to these peers ?
I guess explorer shows the result of /network/peers which happened to be the same ip address of peer host (i.e. Docker network).

And question to this channel.  How do I invoke restAPIs in latest fabric ? Is it gone ?? For example, I run "orderer" and "peer" in native machine, then run "curl localhost:7050/chain" gives me "??" message, and orderer shows like:
```2016/12/13 14:50:35 transport: http2Server.HandleStreams received bogus greeting from client: "GET /chain HTTP/1.1\r\nHos"```
And peer only expose "gRPC port".  Is there any switch to turn on RESTAPI ?
<@U11CP8FF1> its shows the result of rest api. But i need to change the ip address for each peer.
btw according to my knowledge rest api will be deprecate in fabric v1.0

<@U1F1CU61Y> Thanks for rest api info. As for blockchain explorer, I guess you need to modify explorer code to return host ip/port (iptables or docker-compose ps). Or prepare mapping table in a file, and read it in stead of using /network/peers.
but i want to use rest api's . it should return the actual IP Address of machine through API
ankitkamra: I wouldn't build on top of the REST apis, since, as you noted, they're going away

<@U0UHG4VP1> actually i am building an application over fabric-java-sdk and if i register master peer with the sdk, sdk will get information of all renaming peers in the network and will get same address for each peer. now if master peer gets down it will search for docker IP i.e. 172.17.0.1 that does not exist on the network. So i want to know is there any mechanism using which each peer should expose its physical IP.
